 Perot. Daewoo has explained this. Let me quote him.
 
 
Bush I was defeated by Ross Perot. Perot came in and slit the republican vote and handed the presidency to Bill Clinton. 
 
 Going into the election, Bush was seen as unbeatable. The economy had certainly taken a beating, but there was some hope on the horizon, and more importantly, he had brought us through a war victoriously (gulf I). A popular war, no less.
 
 Clionton got a run at the presidency as a sacrificial lamb. The democrats didn't think they could possibly beat bush, so they ran the governer of Arkansas, a guy with kind of a shady background and some pretty serious credibility issues, knowign that he would be beat. Nobody who really felt they had a chance at the oval office wanted to go up against bush Sr.
 
 Perot came in, and despite the fact he was a lunatic, split enough republicans off to cost Bush the election.

 
 http://4forums.com/political/showthread.php?p=105961&highlight=perot#post105961
 
 hence, Perot caused a three way vote, where in this election, there was a two way vote. Think about it this way, 100/3 or 100/2.1?

Thank you lord tammerlain. 
 
 Let me try explain this Marc9000 and I will let your act of poorely read idiocy slide. 
 
 VTCruiser's question was dealing with Clinton's elections and Dubya's elections, specifically how the majorities went.
 
 Clinton's elections were 1992 and 1996 respectively. During the 1992 election, (when Dubya wasnt even in the picture), Perot ran. His campagin, financed with his own money split the republican vote. Normally in this country, in the past 30 years, we have had a 2 party election. Not in 1992, we have a three party election. Bush Sr had a likely win with a majority of votes before Perot came in. When Perot came in, he split Sr's majority. Thus allowing Clinton to win the presidency without a majority vote. 
 
 Clinton 43%
 SR 37.4%
 Perot 18.9%
 Notice, if that 18.9% went to SR, he would have won easily.
 
 the vote is split 3 ways, not two. 
 
 Summary: Perot Split Republican Vote. Clinton win.
 
 In 1996, Perot ran again. Same deal.
 
 Clinton 49.2%
 Dole 40%
 Perot 8.4%. 
 
 Again the vote is split 3 ways, not two. 
 
 Then we have the 2004 election.
 Kerry, Bush and basically no one worth mentioning in terms of votes.
 
 Instead of a three way vote, we have a two way vote. think of that 18.9% or 8.4% being split between the two parties. Hence why I told VT that Clinton's elections were a 100/3, where the 2004 was a 100/2.1. Bush won a majority because there were fewer real people to vote for. Clinton did not because there were more real people to vote for.

 1996 was not the same deal. Perot was relevant in only ONE of the three elections. He had nothing to do with W winning the majority in 2004, and he had nothing to do with Clinton winning in 1996, as the numbers show that even if Dole would have gotten all of Perot's votes, Clinton still would have won with a minority. The Green, Libertarian, and others were the deciding factors in Clinton's minority win. 
 
 The "no one worth mentioning" third parties are more of an influence in the case of a president winning by a minority, far more than the electorial college. Whether that's a bad thing or not is another thread I guess.

 1992, Perot takes votes from Bush, letting Clinton win. Bush would win majority if perot did not win. Vote divided by 3
